question: Which of the following conditions is associated with a tram-track appearance of glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy?
Which one of these effects is observed in a flail chest?
Which of the following conditions is characterized by a spike and dome appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy?
Which type of hypoxia is seen in cyanide poisoning?
'Wire-loop' configuration of glomerular capillaries is seen in?
Which one of these is not a type of proteinuria?
Which of these glomerular diseases is most common in children?
What is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children?

A 40-year-old man comes with the presenting complaint of localized pain in the perineum and suprapubic area, and pain during and after ejaculation. Detailed urine and culture reports show raised white blood cell (WBC) count and growth of E. coli. What would be the diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy presents with a fever. On examination, he is hypertensive having a blood pressure (BP) of 140/90 mmHg. Urine analysis reveals 1+proteinuria, 3+hematuria, no ketones, no glucose, and RBC casts. On renal biopsy, hyper-cellular glomeruli containing neutrophils are noticed. The granular pattern on immune-fluorescence and electron-dense sub-epithelial “humps” on electron microscopy are also present. This child is suffering from which of the following renal diseases?

A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of lethargy and puffiness around his eyes. Laboratory results show serum creatinine and urea nitrogen within normal ranges. Urinalysis shows 4+proteinuria, no blood, glucose, or ketones, and a 24-hour urine protein content of 3.6 g. The child’s condition improves after a course of corticosteroid therapy. Which of the following best describes the underlying renal pathology in this child?

answers.option: Glomerular basement deposition of IgG antibodies

question: Which of these stones is commonly formed as a result of infection?
A 25-year-old woman was taking thiazide diuretics. After one week, she developed a rash and low-grade fever. Her blood complete picture shows increased eosinophil count. What would be the diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male presents with features of nephrotic syndrome. In addition, there is microscopic haematuria. Renal biopsy shows partial sclerosis affecting some of the glomeruli. Sclerosed areas show IgM and C3 on immune fluorescence. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 4-year-old girl presents to the outpatient department with severe pitting edema. Further investigations show hypoalbuminemia, lipiduria, and 3.8 g proteinuria. Biopsy confirms the renal disease. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of proteinuria in this patient?

answers.option: Anti GBM antibodies cross reacting with alveolar basement membranes

question: A 40-year-old female, presented with severe abdominal pain with radiation to her back. Computed tomography (CT) scan showed bilateral ureterolithiasis. Which one of the following is appropriate regarding stones?

A 44-year-old male came for a follow-up checkup with his laboratory results, which showed increased creatinine, urea, and PSA level. The physician suspected benign prostate hypertrophy. What is the most common manifestation of benign prostate hypertrophy?

A 44-year-old man complaints of swelling of legs and puffiness around eyes. His abdomen becomes protuberant and he feels shortness of breath. There is generalized edema and ascites. Total serum protein is 5.2 g/dL (range 5.5-8.0) and albumin is 1.9 g/dL (range 3.5-5.5). Serum cholesterol is 530 mg/dL. There are 5 grams of protein in 24-hr urine collection. The urinary sediment contains many hyaline casts but no RBCs or WBCs. Renal biopsy immunofluorescence shows a granular pattern. Which of the following immunologic mechanisms was most likely responsible for glomerular changes?

answers.option: Cytotoxic T cells directed against renal antigens
Release of cytokines by inflammatory cells
Deposition of immune complexes on basement membrane

question: A 45-year-old patient with kidney failure was diagnosed with polycystic kidney disease. Both adult and childhood polycystic kidney diseases lead to end-stage renal disease and renal failure requiring dialysis. Which of the following is correct for this disease?

answers.option: Is a disease of women only
More commonly appears in the old age
Occurs with the same frequency as autosomal dominant variant

question: A 5-year-old boy presents to the outpatient department with generalized edema and periorbital edema. Further investigations show hypoalbuminemia, lipiduria, and 3.7 g proteinuria. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause in this patient?
A 55-year-old patient is admitted with a massive gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. The patient is at risk for what type of acute kidney injury?

A 58-year-old man noticed blood in his urine and consulted his family physician. On examination, he appears to be in good health. Laboratory results show mild microcytic, hypochromic anemia, and hematuria. X-ray abdomen followed by computed tomography (CT) scan revealed an irregular mass 6 cm in diameter occupying most of his left kidney. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old boy presents with generalized edema and periorbital edema. Further investigations show hypoalbuminemia, lipiduria, and 3.6 g proteinuria. Renal biopsy and electron microscopy were carried out. Which of the following electron microscopic features do you expect to find in this patient?

answers.option: Linear deposits of IgG in the glomerular basement membrane
Loss of foot processes, no deposits

question: A 62-year-old female complains of pain in her right flank. There is tenderness at the right costo-vertebral angle. Laboratory tests show microscopic hematuria but no protein or glucose. Complete blood count (CBC) shows microcytic and hypochromic anemia. Computed tomography (CT) scan reveals an irregular renal mass 5.2 cm in diameter occupying the upper pole of the right kidney. A biopsy is performed and histology shows atypical cells with pleomorphic nuclei and abundant clear cytoplasm. Molecular studies in this patient would most likely identify mutations in which of the following genes?

A 65-year-old male came with the presenting complaints of dysuria, frequency, and urgency. He had a history of right renal transplant. Urine culture showed growth of E. coli. The X-ray showed a contracted kidney with blunting and deformity of the calyces. What would be the diagnosis?
A 66-year-old male presented with the complaint of complete anuria and pain in the groin region. X-ray showed stone below the level of ureters. What would be the diagnosis?

answers.option: Hydronephrosis due to bilateral complete obstruction
Hydronephrosis due to impaired vesicoureteral reflux
Hydronephrosis due to unilateral complete obstruction
Hydronephrosis due to unilateral partial obstruction
Hydronephrosis due to bilateral partial obstruction

question: A 70-year-old male presented with complaints of pain in the groin, hematuria, and anuria. Ultrasound showed unilateral obstruction with dilated pelvis and calyces. The physician diagnosed him with a case of hydronephrosis. What is the site of obstruction?
A diagnosed patient of the nephritic syndrome will complain of:
What is the correct statement regarding polycystic kidney disease in children?
Which cells will be seen upon kidney biopsy in a patient with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?
Which of these conditions is easily confused with renal cell carcinoma?
Which of these risk factors does not predispose to pyelonephritis?
All following statements about renal stones are incorrect except?

answers.option: Pure uric acid stones are radio-lucent
The common bacteria found as a nidus for urinary stones are Streptococci and Pseudomonas
Hyperparathyroidism is found in 50 per cent of those presenting with radio-opaque calculi
A staghorn calculus is composed of calcium-uric acid-magnesium phosphate
If a parathyroid adenoma is found to be the cause of renal calculi, it should not be removed before treatment of the calculus

question: What is the most common cause of nephritic syndrome in children?
Which of the following is correct for acute epididymo-orchitis?

answers.option: In elderly it is often associated with bladder out flow obstruction
Is always clinically distinguishable from testicular torsion

question: An 11-year old boy presents with the complaint of swelling in his feet for the past 4 weeks. He is otherwise in good health and gives no previous history of any illness. Physical examination reveals pitting edema of the lower legs and a swollen abdomen. Urinalysis shows 4+ protein but no RBCs or WBCs.The treating physicians should consider which of the following conditions in this case?

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is an extremely common cause of prostatic enlargement resulting from the proliferation of stromal and glandular elements. The glandular lumina contains inspissated proteinaceous secretory material. The secretory material is known as:
Which of the following is correct for carcinoma of the prostate?

answers.option: Is typically a squamous cell carcinoma
Is graded histologically using the Gleason score
Is not influenced by hormone manipulation
Occurs predominantly in the central zone of the prostate

question: How does testicular torsion typically present?

answers.option: Sudden pain in the scrotum but preserved cremasteric reflex
Sudden pain in the scrotum and an absent cremasteric reflex
Sudden pain in the scrotum and gross hematuria

question: Left ventricular hypertrophy in chronic kidney disease patients can occur due to:
Nephrotic range proteinuria is generally considered:
Patients with progressive chronic renal failure typically develop:
Regarding renal stones, all of the following are true except:

answers.option: Hydronephrosis and/or pyonephrosis with a palpable loin swelling is uncommon
There are very few physical signs
The severity of pain of ureteric colic is related to the size of stone
Renal stones are usually visible on a plain X-ray

question: Resection of an abdominal mass discovered incidentally in a 10-month-old infant by his mother reveals a 10.5 cm well-circumscribed right renal tumor, which is soft in consistency. On slicing, the tumor a pale gray solid surface is noted with cystic areas, necrosis, and hemorrhage. Microscopically, the tumor is composed of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial tissues. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
The term 'pyonephrosis' is used to describe which of the following?

answers.option: Collecion of pus in Gerota's fascia

question: Which of the following terms is consistent with ischemic tubular necrosis of kidneys?
Which of these cystic disorders is characterized by cysts at the corticomedullar junction?
Which of these features regarding congenital cystic kidney disease is false?
Sub-epithelial humps on electron microscopy of glomerulus are characteristic of?
A glomerular disease is strongly associated with hepatitis B and presents as nephrotic syndrome. Which of these pathologic features is consistent with this disease?

answers.option: Spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy

question: Which of the following regions of nephrons is most affected in toxin-mediated acute tubular necrosis?

answers.option: Descending limb of loop of Henle
Ascending limb of loop of Henle

question: What is the most common type of kidney stone?
Which of these diseases resembles IgA nephropathy?
Which of these glomerular diseases is characterized by the 'tram-track' appearance of the glomerular basement membrane?
What is the most common site of metastasis for renal cell carcinoma?
What is the most common kidney tumor in children?
Which of these disorders display hypocomplementemia?

The leading cause of death among patients with an end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is:
The most common systemic disease causing end-stage renal disease globally is:

answers.option: All causes of renal vasculitis (e.g., Wegener’s)

question: The most ominous sign or symptom of the urinary disease is:

answers.option: Are typical well demonstrated by CT scan
Can be dissolved by treatment with allopurinol
Are the most common upper tract calculi
Occurs less frequently after treatment with penicillamine

question: Which of the following is correct for ureteral obstruction (unilateral)?

answers.option: Is commonly caused by a urinary tract calculus
Is usually associated with infection behind the obstruction
Usually requires open surgical relief of the obstruction
Is associated with increase in urea and creatinine

question: Voiding urinary symptoms include all about except:

answers.option: Feeling of incomplete emptying of urinary bladder

question: Which of the following is not a classical feature of the nephrotic syndrome?
Which patient below is NOT at risk for developing nephrotic syndrome?

answers.option: A 5-year-old female diagnosed with minimal change disease
A 7-year-old male recently diagnosed with Alport syndrome

question: You're collecting a urine sample on a patient who is experiencing proteinuria due to nephrotic syndrome. As the doctor, you know the urine will appear:

A female athlete presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal cramps and vomiting after running for miles. Upon examination, she looked dehydrated and was losing consciousness. What is the probable reason behind her condition?

Which of the following conditions is characterized by hypokalemia with normal blood pressure?
Which of the following is the most common radiopaque renal stone?
Which of the following is the most common radiolucent renal stone?

A female patient presents to the clinic with a history of severe joint pain and a rash on her face in the shape of a butterfly that involves the bridges of the nose. She also has periorbital edema and the urine sample shows hematuria. What is the most likely cause of her condition?

A female patient presents to the clinic with a history of severe joint pain and a rash on her face in the shape of a butterfly that involves the bridges of the nose. She also has periorbital edema and the urine sample shows hematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis of her condition?

A patient presents to the outpatient department with recurrent urinary tract infection and flank pain. Upon investigation, envelope-shaped crystals are found deposited in the kidney. Which of the following is the composition of the crystals?
Which of the following is the least likely cause of acute pyelonephritis?
Which of the following morphological change is characteristically seen in minimal change disease?

answers.option: Sclerosis of particular segments of some glomeruli
Crescent-shape seen in the Bowman space of glomeruli
Thickened glomerular membranes with "spike and dome" epithelial deposits
Normal basement membrane with fusion of foot process
Thickened glomerular membranes with a "tram-track" appearance

question: The presence of which of the following casts are highly suggestive of acute tubular necrosis?

What is the commonest presentation of bladder cancer?
Which of the following does not cause hyperkalemia?
Which of the following is a characteristic finding of nephritic syndrome?

A 22-year-old female presented with abrupt onset of hematuria, hypertension, and peripheral edema. Initial investigations show transient renal dysfunction with protein and red blood cell casts in urine. What is the likely diagnosis as per presentation in this case?
SIADH is characterized by which of the following?

A 58-year-old male presents with pain and tenderness at the right costovertebral angle. Laboratory investigations reveal microscopic haematuria but no protein or glucose. A complete blood count report shows microcytic hypochromic anemia. CT scan reveals an irregular renal mass 6 cm in diameter near the upper pole of the right kidney. Biopsy reveals atypical cells with abundant clear cytoplasm. Molecular studies would most likely identify mutations in which of the following growth regulatory genes?

A middle-aged man experiences increasing malaise, nausea with reduced urine output for the past two days. Laboratory investigations show a raised serum creatinine of 2.7mg/dl. Urinalysis shows hematuria. Renal biopsy reveals granular pattern on immunofluorescence. Which of the following best describes this patient's medical condition?

A 70-year-old male presents with complaints of pain in the groin, hematuria, and anuria. Ultrasound shows complete bilateral obstruction with dilated pelvis and calyces. The physician diagnoses him with hydronephrosis. What is the site of obstruction?

Which of the following diseases frequently presents with hematuria?

A 9-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of cola-colored urine. He has a past history of being treated for a sore throat infection 3 weeks ago. His blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg. Urinalysis reveals red cell casts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis?
A lesion at which vertebral level will cause paralysis of all 4 limbs?
In acute nephritic syndrome, children and young adults are affected. Which is the most common age range for nephritic syndrome?

The mother of a 9-month-old boy notices a mass on the right side of the infant's abdomen. Resection of the mass reveals a 10 cm well-circumscribed tumor which is of soft consistency. The cut section of the tumor is predominantly solid and pale gray with areas of cystic change, necrosis, and hemorrhage. Microscopically, the tumor is composed of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial tissues. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) is an extremely common cause of prostatic enlargement resulting from the proliferation of stromal and glandular elements. The enlargement of the prostate in men with BPH is an important cause of urinary obstruction. Which zone is commonly involved in benign prostatic hyperplasia?

A 20-year-old-man comes with flank pain and urinary symptoms. He is diagnosed with having polycystic kidney disease. His family has a known mutation in the PKHD1 gene. PKHD1 gene, coding for a membrane receptor protein called fibrocystin is implicated in which of the following?

A 12-year-old girl has a history of throat infection with group A (ß-hemolytic) streptococci. Now she presents with hypertension, oliguria, and hematuria. Renal biopsy shows glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is the congenital anomaly in which both the kidneys are connected by their lower poles?

answers.option: Fluid secreted by the fallopian tubes
Sebaceous secretions composed of sloughed-off epithelial cells

question: Which of the following deposits are found in post-streptococcal glomerular nephritis?

answers.option: Latency less than 10 days in throat infection

question: Which of the following is the most common primary cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults?
Which of the following is the earliest sign of capillary changes in nephrotic syndrome?

A 70-year-old man was was advised to get an ultrasound done. The ultrasound report showed bilateral enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts. What is the probable diagnosis?
Which of the following renal calculi deposit as a result of some genetic defect in reabsorption of amino acid by kidney?
A 7-year-old child was brought to the emergency department with complaint of hematuria. Upon examination, the child had a palpable mass in the lumbar region. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following conditions cannot be distinguished from chromophobe?
Which of the following conditions present with painless gross hematuria?
In which of the following conditions, heavy proteinuria would be seen in an elderly man?
Which of the following features suggests intrinsic renal failure?
Hyperplastic arteriolitis is seen in which of the following conditions?

answers.option: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

question: A 12-year-old boy was being investigated for a kidney tumor. The doctor found no tumor but a unilateral multicystic kidney was found. Which of the following is true about his condition?

answers.option: Congenital malformation of the renal parenchyma
Most common genetic cause of ESRD in chidren

question: A 23-year-old man died and the cause of death was found to be a berry aneurysm. On autopsy, multiple, enlarged cystic kidneys were found. Which of the following is true for the deceased's condition?

answers.option: Due to mutation in the APKD1 or APKD2 gene
Autosomal recessive form usually presents in young adults
Congenital malformation of the renal parenchyma

question: A 26-year-old woman who has been sexually active for 5 years gave birth to a baby 3 years ago. Upon per vaginal examination, what is the finding?
'Stretch marks' seen in pregnancy are termed as which of the following?
A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with a case of renal stones. He also has a long-term history of gout and diabetes. Which of the following renal stones are most likely formed in his case?
Which of the following is the surest sign of recent delivery?
Regarding childhood type of polycystic kidney disease, which of the following statements is true?

answers.option: It usually manifests in the renal parenchyma

question: A 62-year-old man comes into the clinic with complaints of fever, hematuria, and hemoptysis. Renal biopsy reveals linear deposition of IgG and complement (C3) along the basement membrane. What is the most likely diagnosis for his condition?
A 28-year-old woman, in her third month of pregnancy, came to the clinic with complaints of raised bumps around her areola. What are these bumps called?

A 41-year-old has had recurrent urinary tract infections for 15 years. On many of these occasions, Proteus mirabilis was cultured from his urine. For the past 4 days, he has had burning pain while urinating, and urinary frequency. On examination, his temperature is 37.9°C, pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. There is marked tenderness on deep pressure over the right costovertebral angle and on deep abdominal palpation. Urinalysis shows a pH of 7.5, specific gravity 1.020, 1+ hematuria, and no protein, glucose, or ketones. Microscopic examination of the urine shows many RBCs, WBCs, and triple phosphate crystals. Which of the following renal lesions is most likely to be present?
What is the most common causative organism for acute pyelonephritis?

A 60-year-old male presented with complaints of anuria. He was investigated and diagnosed with prostatic carcinoma. Imaging studies show dilatation of the renal pelvis. A cut section of the kidney shows a dilated pelvis and calyces, as well as thinning of the renal parenchyma. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 34-year-old man is awakened at night because of severe lower abdominal pain that radiates to the groin. The pain is very intense and comes in waves. The next morning, he notices blood in his urine. He has no underlying illnesses and has been healthy all his life. Urinalysis shows a pH of 7; specific gravity of 1.020; and no protein, glucose, ketones, or nitrite. The patient is advised to drink more water. He likes iced tea and consumes large quantities over the course of a hot summer. He continues to have similar episodes. Which of the following substances is most likely to be increased in his urine?
Which of the following is not a cause of unilateral hydronephrosis?

A 69-year-old man comes to the hospital with end-stage renal failure. He gives a history of analgesic use for arthritis and occasional social alcohol use. He reports that 20 years ago he was told by a doctor that some of his blood tests related to his kidneys were abnormal and was advised to attend hospital for follow up. However, he felt fine so he went to live in his village and did not attend hospital until now. Ultrasound of his kidneys shows markedly enlarged kidneys bilaterally with multiple cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding the pathogenesis of this disease?

answers.option: Most likely due to chemicals and toxins in the water at his village

question: A 45-year-old lady is booked for a cholecystectomy. During her preoperative workup, radiological investigations reveal multiple cystic dilations of the collecting ducts in the renal medulla. No cortical scarring is present and renal function is normal. What is the most likely cause of these findings?

A 6-year-old child undergoes surgical exploration and nephrectomy for a suspected kidney tumor. His ultrasound shows an enlarged multicystic, irregular left kidney. Biopsy shows no tumor. However, there are islands of undifferentiated mesenchyme and cartilage. Which of the following is correct regarding this disease?

answers.option: Commonest genetic cause of end stage renal disease in children
It is rarely associated with other lower urinary tract anomalies

question: An 82-year-old man passed away in the hospital. He had a history of frequent urinary problems. His body underwent a medical autopsy. The report mentions "scarring of both kidneys". What might this be a feature of?

A patient on acetaminophen developed renal symptoms and was diagnosed with drug-induced acute kidney injury. Acute kidney injury can result from exposure to toxins or ischemia. What is it characterized by?

answers.option: Increased glomerular filtration rate and increased urinary creatinine
Increased glomerular filtration rate and oliguria
Decreased glomerular filtration rate and oliguria

question: A 70-year-old woman is admitted for a fainting spell with no history of trauma. Blood pressure is 110/60 (lying down) and 60/40 (sitting). Recently, she was prescribed diuretics for cardiac problems. Which of the following drugs might be responsible for her condition?
Which of the following is the most common cause of urinary tract infections in females?
Which of the following is the most common organism responsible for causing nephritic syndrome?

A 24-hour urine collection test demonstrates oliguria and urinalysis shows hematuria. What finding in his urinalysis would suggest that the hematuria is caused by kidney involvement and not by bleeding from the urinary bladder?

An 8-year-old boy becomes increasingly lethargic. On physical examination, he has swelling in his legs and ankles. Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria and no blood or glucose. 24-hour urine protein loss is 3.8 g. Immunofluorescence microscopy of renal biopsy is unremarkable. The child's condition improves after a course of corticosteroid therapy. Which of the following morphologic alteration is most likely to be responsible for his condition?

Which of the following is least likely to be seen in nephrotic syndrome?

Which of the following conditions is the most important cause of hydronephrosis?
Linear deposition of IgG on the basement membrane is seen in which of the following conditions?
A patient presents with hemoptysis, renal failure, and anti-basement membrane antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which renal calculi are common in diseases having rapid cell turnover?

A 50-year-old female patient comes to the outpatient department with frothy urine, edema, and low urine output. She has been a known case of diabetes and hypertension for almost 20 years. Her laboratory reports show increased creatinine levels and is diagnosed with diabetic nephropathy. What is the histological appearance of diabetic nephropathy?

Which of the following defects is found in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease on a molecular level?
Both adult and childhood polycystic kidney disease cause end-stage renal disease. What is correct regarding autosomal recessive cystic kidney disease?

answers.option: Mostly occur in both adults and children

question: A patient presented to the clinic with the symptoms of the nephrotic syndrome. Upon investigation, his glomeruli were found to be thick, and hypercellular with a double contouring of the glomerular basement membrane. There were thick subendothelial electron-dense deposits clearly visible. His serum levels showed hypocomplementemia, especially low levels of C3. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis in this case?

answers.option: Leads to renal failure in early stage
It has to be differentiated with the renal carcinoma

question: Which of the following would have decreased serum levels in immune complex-mediated injury to the kidney?
Which of the following is an indication of acute tubular necrosis caused by toxins?

A 20-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria and edema. She had a history of sore throat around 14 days back. Upon investigation, it was found that her urine contained red blood cell casts and mild proteinuria while microscopy showed crescentic proliferation of glomerular epithelial cells and segmental glomerular necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 12-year-old boy presented to the outpatient department with the complaint of hematuria and proteinuria. He has a history of a skin infection that presented with blisters. Upon investigation by immunofluorescence microscopy, there were granular deposits of IgG and C3, and sometimes IgM in the mesangium along the glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 3-year-old boy presents with fever, dysuria, oliguria, and intense pain in the abdomen. Physical examination shows a prominent suprapubic area which is dull on percussion. Urinalysis reveals red blood cells but no proteinuria. A diagnosis of hydronephrosis was made. What is the important morphological feature of hydronephrosis?

answers.option: Cortical scarring and shrinking caused by thickening and hyalinization of the vessel walls
Cortical tubulointerstitial damage with small contracted kidney
Patchy interstitial suppurative inflammation, intratubular aggregates of neutrophilic tubulitis, and tubular necrosis
Dilatation of renal calyces and pelvis with atrophy of renal parenchyma
Enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts in the cortex and medulla

question: An 8-month-old infant was diagnosed with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease. Which one of the following other abnormalities can develop in this patient?

answers.option: It is more common in males
The most common causative agent is E. coli
It can be caused by ascending infection from the bladder or through hematogenous dissemination
It is more common in females

question: A 45-year-old woman has angina pectoris, polyuria, and polydipsia for the past 5 years. On physical examination, she has a body mass index (BMI) of 32 kg/m². Laboratory studies show an HbA1C of 10%. Urinalysis shows macroalbuminuria, with no ketonuria. Which one of the following morphological changes can be attributed to the patient's proteinuria?
Which of the following is not a filtration barrier in kidneys?

answers.option: Negative charge in the glomerular basement membrane

question: Nephrotic syndrome is a clinical complex characterized by massive proteinuria of 3.5 gm or more of protein loss per 24 hours, hypoalbuminemia, generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, and lipiduria. Which of the following causes of nephrotic syndrome is steroid-responsive?

Loss of which of the following renal functions is most likely to be identified by laboratory measurement of the urine-specific gravity following water deprivation?

A 30-year-old man complains of puffiness around his eyes and swelling of his feet for 2 weeks. On examination, his blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Urine microscopic examination reveals oval fat bodies. Which of the following conditions is he most likely to have?

Tubulointerstitial nephritis is inflammation that affects the tubules and the tissue surrounding them called "Interstitial tissue." The onset of tubulointerstitial nephritis may be acute (sudden) or chronic (gradual) and often results in kidney failure. Which of the following is the most common cause of acute tubulointerstitial nephritis?

answers.option: Damage from a drug (not an allergic reaction)

question: A 6-year-old boy presents with generalized body swelling and decreased urine output. His lab investigations show a serum albumin of 2.5 g/dl, serum creatinine of 0.5 mg/dl , a serum cholesterol of 250 mg/dl and urine dipstick reveals 3+ proteinuria, no RBC or RBC casts. Based on the clinical and laboratory findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A 24-year-old female presents with decreased urination and hematuria for 2 days. She has been unwell for the past 15 days with severe sore throat and high-grade fever with chills. On examination, her blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg, pulse is 94/min, and temperature is 100°F. Systemic and general physical examinations were unremarkable. Which of the following urinary casts is most specific for her illness?

A 50-year-old male is admitted to the medical ward with a history of abdominal distention and pedal edema. He is diagnosed with chronic liver disease (Cirrhosis). Laboratory investigations show the following: CBC: Hb 10 g/dL, WBC 3 x 10³/mm³, Platelets 105 x 10³/mm³ Serum Albumin: 2.7 g/dL Prothrombin time: 18 sec (Control: 11-14 sec) Serum Sodium: 122 mEq/L Serum Potassium: 3.6 mEq/L Serum Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL What is the cause of hyponatremia in this patient based on his history and physical examination?
